body:
I can't reproduce with the sample provided. What is NetworkManager.h in this instance?

Please compile libcache with debug symbols enabled (cmake -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Debug) and launch Sublime Text 2 in a gdb session. When the crash happens, type "t a a bt" in the gdb console and paste the stack trace here.

Ok, found NetworkManager.h and was able to reproduce. This is however an issue with libclang rather than SublimeClang specifically:

```
sublime_text: /home/quarnster/.config/sublime-text-2/Packages/SublimeClang/src/build/llvm/tools/clang/lib/AST/Type.cpp:1850: clang::TemplateSpecializationType::TemplateSpecializationType(clang::TemplateName, const clang::TemplateArgument*, unsigned int, clang::QualType, clang::QualType): Assertion `(!Canon.isNull() || T.isDependent() || anyDependentTemplateArguments(Args, NumArgs, InstantiationDependent)) && "No canonical type for non-dependent class template specialization"' failed.

Program received signal SIGABRT, Aborted.
[Switching to Thread 0x7fff7affd700 (LWP 3541)]

```

The same issue can be created without any of SublimeClang's code with this small test:
```c++
// gcc test.cpp -L .config/sublime-text-2/Packages/SublimeClang/ -lclang -o ./test && LD_LIBRARY_PATH=~/.config/sublime-text-2/Packages/SublimeClang/src/build/llvm/build/lib ./test
// Save your code as bug.cpp and this test as test.cpp
#include "clang-c/Index.h"
#include <stdio.h>

int main(int argc, char** argv)
{
    CXIndex idx = clang_createIndex(1, 0);
    const char *clangargs[] =
    {
        "-isystem", ".config/sublime-text-2/Packages/SublimeClang/clang/include/",
        "-isystem", "/",
        "-I/usr/include/qt4",
        "-I/usr/include/glib-2.0",
        "-I/usr/include/NetworkManager",
        "-I/usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/glib-2.0/include/"
    };

    // Parse the source file into a translation unit
    CXTranslationUnit tu = clang_parseTranslationUnit(idx,
        "bug.cpp",
        clangargs, sizeof(clangargs)/sizeof(char*),
        NULL, 0,
        CXTranslationUnit_PrecompiledPreamble);

    if (!tu)
    {
        printf("Couldn't parse tu\n");
        clang_disposeIndex(idx);
        return 1;
    }
    clang_reparseTranslationUnit(tu, 0, NULL, clang_defaultReparseOptions(tu));

    // Show any diagnostic information if available
    for (unsigned int i = 0; i < clang_getNumDiagnostics(tu); i++)
    {
        CXDiagnostic diag = clang_getDiagnostic(tu, i);
        CXString s = clang_getDiagnosticSpelling(diag);
        printf("%s\n", clang_getCString(s));
        clang_disposeString(s);
        clang_disposeDiagnostic(diag);
    }
    printf("Total diagnostics available: %d\n", clang_getNumDiagnostics(tu));
    clang_disposeTranslationUnit(tu);
    clang_disposeIndex(idx);

    return 0;
}
```

You can try to see if the latest [llvm from svn](http://llvm.org/docs/GettingStarted.html#checkout) has still has this issue, search for or file a bug if it doesn't exist already in [llvm's bug tracker](http://llvm.org/bugs/). Closing as it's not a SublimeClang issue.

Also as the crash is due to an assert, it can be removed by compiling libclang in Release mode. Presuming you let the SublimeClang build system download and compile libclang:
```
cd ~/.config/sublime-text-2/Packages/SublimeClang/src/build
rm -f ../../libclang.so
rm -rf llvm/build/
rm -f CMakeCache.txt
cmake -DCMAKE_BUILD_TYPE=Release ..
mkdir llvm/build
make
```
compiling in release mode stops the constant crashing, thanks for you quick replies!
